title: 107_s2449
content: The Act titled "Federal Responsibility for Immigrant Health Act of 2002" allows federal payments under Medicaid for emergency medical conditions of certain aliens. The Social Security Act is amended to include necessary care and services for emergency medical conditions, pregnancy-related services, and communicable disease testing or treatment for certain aliens. Additionally, states have the option to eliminate residency requirements for aliens granted parole or admitted as nonimmigrant aliens. Aliens granted parole or admitted as nonimmigrant aliens may be exempt from residency requirements under the Social Security Act. These amendments apply to medical assistance provided after the enactment of the Act. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens is allocated as follows: $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2001, and $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2007. State allotments are determined based on the percentage of undocumented aliens in each state, with the 15 states with the highest percentage receiving specific allotments for fiscal years 2003 to 2007. The Secretary of Health and Human Services computes allotments for the 15 states with the highest percentage of undocumented aliens for fiscal years 2003 to 2007. Allotments are based on the ratio of undocumented aliens in each state to the total, with unused funds carried over to the next fiscal year. The Secretary of Health and Human Services computes allotments for states with the highest percentage of undocumented aliens for fiscal years 2003 to 2007. Unused funds are carried over to the next fiscal year for payment to hospitals and providers of emergency health services to undocumented aliens. The Secretary of Health and Human Services allocates funds to states with high undocumented alien populations for emergency health services. Funds are paid to hospitals and providers in impacted areas based on approved state plans or alternative measures. The Secretary of Health and Human Services allocates funds to states with high undocumented alien populations for emergency health services, including hospitals and providers. Definitions and special rules are provided for the allocation of funds, with specific criteria for hospitals, providers, and related services. Amounts paid under this subsection are specified. The amendments made by this section allocate funds for emergency health services to states with high undocumented alien populations, with specific criteria for hospitals and providers. Amounts paid under this subsection are not to be substituted for Federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act or used for the State share of expenditures under title XIX. Effective starting fiscal year 2003. SEC. 4. Permitting states and localities to provide health care to all individuals. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to exclude health benefits provided by state or local governments from the definition of assistance. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to exclude health benefits provided by state or local governments from the definition of assistance. This amendment applies to health care provided before, on, or after the enactment of the Act.
